docs.lead_paragraph: DOES television have any documented positive effects on its viewers'b ehavior, effects that might counter, or at least mitigate, the n egative aspects that have recently been in the headlines? The a nswer, according to a number of researchers, appears to be a most d efinite yes, but. Last May the long debate over the effects of television on violent behavior reached a new level with the release of the federally sponsored report that updated the 1972 Surgeon General's study on the subject. In the new report the National Institute of Mental Health concluded that there was ''overwhelming'' scientific evidence that ''excessive'' violence on television led directly to aggression and violent behavior among children and teen-agers. The conclusion was based on 2,500 studies published by researchers since 1970.
